definition: a mammal that feeds on ants and termites, with a long snout and sticky tongue
a nocturnal badger-sized burrowing mammal of Africa, with long ears, a tubular snout, and a long extensible tongue, feeding on ants and termites
a heavily built omnivorous nocturnal mammal of the weasel family, typically having a grey and black coat
a great ape with large ears, mainly black coloration, and lighter skin on the face, native to the forests of west and central Africa
a fast-flying long-bodied predatory insect with two pairs of large transparent wings which are spread out sideways at rest
the largest penguin, which has a yellow patch on each side of the head and rears its young during the Antarctic winter
a tall wading bird with mainly pink or scarlet plumage and long legs and neck
a large African mammal with a very long neck and forelegs, having a coat patterned with brown patches separated by lighter lines
a medium to large tropical Old World bird, having a very large curved bill that typically has a large horny or bony casque
a large arboreal tropical American lizard with a spiny crest along the back and greenish coloration
a graceful antelope often seen in large herds in open woodland in southern and East Africa
a free-swimming marine coelenterate with a gelatinous bell- or saucer-shaped body that is typically transparent and has stinging tentacles around the edge
an often brightly coloured bird with a large head and long sharp beak, typically diving for fish from a perch
an aquatic or terrestrial annelid worm with suckers at both ends. Many species are bloodsucking parasites, especially of vertebrates, and others are predators
a devil ray that occurs in tropical seas and may reach very great size
a small Arctic whale, the male of which has a long forward-pointing spirally twisted tusk developed from one of its teeth
a large mainly solitary arboreal ape with long red hair, long arms, and hooked hands and feet, native to Borneo and Sumatra
another term for killer whale
a flightless swift-running African bird with a long neck, long legs, and two toes on each foot. It is the largest living bird
a semiaquatic egg-laying mammal which frequents lakes and streams in eastern Australia
a stout-bodied marine or freshwater fish that typically has spiny skin and inflates itself like a balloon when threatened

a small short-tailed Old World game bird resembling a tiny partridge, typically having brown camouflaged plumage or a small or medium-sized New World game bird, the male of which has distinctive facial markings
a large, heavily built plant-eating mammal with one or two horns on the nose and thick folded skin, native to Africa and southern Asia
a large deep-bodied marine fish of warm seas, with tall dorsal and anal fins near the rear of the body and a very short tail
a heavily built marsupial with a large head, powerful jaws, and mainly black fur, found only in Tasmania

a large bird of prey with the head and neck more or less bare of feathers, feeding chiefly on carrion and reputed to gather with others in anticipation of the death of a sick or injured animal or person
a social winged insect which has a narrow waist and a sting and is typically yellow with black stripes
a burrowing plant-eating Australian marsupial which resembles a small bear with short legs
a large domesticated wild ox with shaggy hair, humped shoulders, and large horns, used in Tibet as a pack animal and for its milk, meat, and hide
an African wild horse with black-and-white stripes and an erect mane
an instrument for measuring the speed of the wind, or of any current of gas
the envelope of gases surrounding the earth or another planet
an instrument measuring atmospheric pressure, used especially in forecasting the weather and determining altitude
a scale of wind speed based on a visual estimation of the wind's effects, ranging from force 0 (less than 1 knot or 1 km/h, ‘calm’) to force 12 (64 knots or 118 km/h and above, ‘hurricane’)

a change in global or regional climate patterns, in particular a change apparent from the mid to late 20th century onwards and attributed largely to the increased levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide produced by the use of fossil fuels
a system of winds rotating inwards to an area of low barometric pressure, with an anticlockwise (northern hemisphere) or clockwise (southern hemisphere) circulation
light rain falling in very fine drops
a strong, turbulent wind which carries clouds of fine dust, soil, and sand over a large area
a sudden local flood, typically due to heavy rain
a very strong wind
an obscuration of the lower atmosphere, typically caused by fine suspended particles
a prolonged period of abnormally hot weather
an instrument for measuring the humidity of the air or a gas
fog formed of minute ice crystals
a breeze blowing towards the sea from the land, especially at night, owing to the relative warmth of the sea
a region where the air pressure is lower than that of surrounding locations
the branch of science concerned with the processes and phenomena of the atmosphere, especially as a means of forecasting the weather
a seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and SE Asia, blowing from the south-west between May and September and bringing rain, or from the north-east between October and April
(of the sky or weather) marked by a covering of grey cloud

a colourless unstable toxic gas with a pungent odour and powerful oxidizing properties, formed from oxygen by electrical discharges or ultraviolet light. It differs from normal oxygen (O2) in having three atoms in its molecule
a thick subsurface layer of soil that remains below freezing point throughout the year, occurring chiefly in polar regions
rain, snow, sleet, or hail that falls to or condenses on the ground

an arch of colours visible in the sky, caused by the refraction and dispersion of the sun's light by rain or other water droplets in the atmosphere. The colours of the rainbow are generally said to be red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet
the amount of water vapour present in air expressed as a percentage of the amount needed for saturation at the same temperature

each of the four divisions of the year (spring, summer, autumn, and winter) marked by particular weather patterns and daylight hours, resulting from the earth's changing position with regard to the sun
a brief and typically light fall of rain while the sun is shining
a crash of thunder
violent or unsteady movement of air or water, or of some other fluid
a rotating column of water and spray formed by a whirlwind occurring over the sea or other body of water
a revolving pointer to show the direction of the wind, typically mounted on top of a building
the quality of dealing with ideas rather than details
a process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer
not involving or relating to the use of computer technology, as a contrast to a digital counterpart
computer software designed to perform a group of coordinated functions, tasks, or activities for the benefit of end users

the theory and development of computer systems able to perform tasks normally requiring human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and translation between languages
extremely large data sets that may be analysed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behaviour and interactions
relating to, using, or denoting a system of numerical notation that has 2 rather than 10 as a base
denoting a system of algebraic notation used to represent logical propositions by means of the binary digits 0 (false) and 1 (true), especially in computing and electronics
a group of binary digits or bits (usually eight) operated on as a unit
in object-oriented programming, an extensible program-code-template for creating objects
a piece of computer hardware or software that accesses a service made available by a server
the practice of using a network of remote servers hosted on the Internet to store, manage, and process data, rather than a local server or a personal computer
a program that converts instructions into a machine-code or lower-level form so that they can be read and executed by a computer
the action of mathematical calculation
the practice and study of techniques for secure communication in the presence of third parties called adversaries
the state of being protected against the criminal or unauthorized use of electronic data, or the measures taken to achieve this
a background process that handles requests for services such as print spooling and file transfers, and is dormant when not required
a large group of networked computer servers typically used by organizations for the remote storage, processing, or distribution of large amounts of data
a specialized format for organizing, processing, retrieving and storing data
copy (data) from one computer system to another, typically over the Internet
the process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access

a device or program enabling a user to communicate with a computer or a device or program for connecting two items of hardware or software so that they can be operated jointly or communicate with each other
a program that can analyse and execute a program line by line
the most basic level or core of an operating system, responsible for resource allocation, file management, and security

a collection of programs and software packages made generally available, often consisting of configuration data, documentation, help data, message templates, pre-written code and subroutines, classes, values, or type specifications
the low-level software that supports a computer's basic functions, such as scheduling tasks and controlling peripherals
run (the processor of one's computer) at a speed higher than that intended by the manufacturers
the process of writing computer programs
a series of sets of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices
occurs when a thing is defined in terms of itself or of its type. For example, functions which contain code that call themselves
the mathematical study of continuous change, in the same way that geometry is the study of shape and algebra is the study of generalizations of arithmetic operations
a formula for computing the derivative of the composition of two or more functions
a mathematical series where the sequence of its partial sums tend to a limit
an expression representing the rate of change of a function with respect to an independent variable
the number e, evaluating to roughly 2.71828
of or expressed by a mathematical exponent
the degree of steepness of a graph at any point
relating to a hyperbola
a function that always returns the same value that was used as its argument or: f(x) = x
(of a number or quantity) expressed in terms of the square root of a negative number (usually the square root of −1, represented by i or j)
a change of curvature from convex to concave at a particular point on a curve
existing or measured at a particular instant
a function of which a given function is the derivative, i.e. which yields that function when differentiated, and which may express the area under the curve of a graph of the function
a quantity representing the power to which a fixed number (the base) must be raised to produce a given number
a symmetrical open plane curve formed by the intersection of a cone with a plane parallel to its side. The path of a projectile under the influence of gravity follows a curve of this shape
the process of starting with the simplified fraction and taking it apart to find its initial polynomial fractions
a process that finds the integral of a product of functions in terms of the integral of the product of their derivative and antiderivative
an expression of more than two algebraic terms, especially the sum of several terms that contain different powers of the same variable(s)
a formula for finding the derivative of a function that is the ratio of two functions
an expression or function so related to another that their product is unity or the quantity obtained by dividing the number one by a given quantity
(of a quantity) having only magnitude, not direction
a method of solving f(x) <= g(x) <= h(x) by finding the point where f(x) = h(x)
a point on a curve where the gradient is zero
the process of adding things together
a straight line or plane that touches, but does not intersect, a curve or curved surface
the branch of mathematics dealing with the relations of the sides and angles of triangles and with the relevant functions of any angles
a value that is greater than or equal to every element of a set of data
a quantity which during a calculation is assumed to vary or be capable of varying in value
